PaintPot Enhancements

Make one or more of the following enhancements to your PaintPot app:

  • Implement a plus button and implement a minus button, which should add/subtract 1 from the dotsize each time it is clicked.
  • Add a reset button that, when clicked, sets the dotsize back to its initial value (i.e., 5). (HINT: You'll need a second variable here to remember the initial value of the dotsize.)
  • Challenging: A bug is an error or defect, that prevents the app from working the way it is supposed to. In this app, if the user continues to press ButtonMinus, the value of dotsize will eventually become negative. If dotsize is negative, what will be drawn when the user touches the screen? Try fixing this bug by using an If/Else statement. (Hint: The If/Else block is found under Control in the Blocks Editor Toolbox.)
  • Create one or more of your own enhancements for your app.

Perform the following steps to add your completed apps to your Google Sites Portfolio:

  1. In App Inventor, package your app by selecting Build and downloading the .apk to your computer.
  2. Go to Google Drive and upload the .apk file.
  3. Right click on the file in Google Drive. Change the sharing settings on your .apk file.
  4. Right click on the file in Google Drive. Click on Show link. Copy the link.
  5. In Google Sites, on your Creative Projects page, select the Insert menu and choose Link. Paste the link as a Web Addresss. Save the page.

I Have A Dream Enhancements

Make one or more of the following enhancements to your I Have A Dream app:

  • Give the app its own custom icon that will appear in the device's app launcher (Hint: Look in the Screen's properties);
  • Use App Inventor's Text-to-Speech component (Media drawer) to get the app to speak some words instead of playing a speech when the Malcolm X button is pressed
  • Have the app vibrate the phone as well as play a speech when the MLK button is pressed (Hint: the Sound component has a Vibrate block. NOTE: You will not be able to test this on the emulator. Also, not all Android devices have a vibrate mode, which is usually a Sound setting. For example, Nexus 7 tablets can not vibrate.)
  • Use App Inventor's Accelerometer Sensor (Sensor drawer) to trigger Malcolm X's Text-to-Speech when the device is shaken. (NOTE: You will not be able to test this on the emulator.)

Reflection: Start a new reflection (Reflection 4). Respond to the following prompts:

  • Describe your I Have A Dream soundboard app. What UI components does it use? How does it work?
  • Now that you've had some experience building apps in App Inventor, what do you think about programming. Is it a creative activity? In what ways does it allow you to express yourself?

I Have A Dream

Download the IHaveADreamStarter.aia project source file. Follow the I Have A Dream tutorial (start with importing the starter app). Ignore the section about setting up the AI2 Companion; you will use the emulator instead.

Reflection: Start a new reflection in your portfolio called Reflection 3. Respond to the following prompts:

  • Why are "if" blocks used in the "I Have a Dream" app?
  • What are some of the elements that make up the UI for a car? An ATM machine?
  • Is it possible to create an app without event driven programming? Explain.

PaintPot

I have installed the aiStarter application so that you can now test your HelloPurr app from yesterday in the emulator. To start the aiStarter application, open it from Start Menu > All Programs > Programming tools > aiStarter

The next app you will make today will make improvements to your HelloPurr app. You may start a new project or make a copy of your existing HelloPurr project. Here are the two parts of the PaintPot app that you will complete today:

  • PaintPot (Part 1)
  • PaintPot (Part 2)

Make sure to test your app. When you are finished, write a reflection (name it Reflection 2) in your Google Sites portfolio that explains in your own words what is happening in the Canvas1.Touched event compared to the Canvas1.Drag events.

HelloPurr

Today you will create your first App Inventor project. Read and follow the directions for the HelloPurr app.

After you get your HelloPurr app working, write a reflection in Google Sites portfolio. Create a new page named Reflection 1 and put the page under Reflections. On your new page, answer the following prompts:

  • How could we describe “event-driven programming” to someone who is not familiar with this concept?
  • What UI components did you use in your app?

Welcome to Computer Science Principles!

Welcome to Computer Science Principles!

Here are the rules for Classcraft for you to look over: ClasscraftRules

Please complete the following two tasks today:

  • Fill out the Tech Survey. I will use this information to setup your Piazza and Classcraft accounts so do this first.
    • Tech Survey link
  • Setup your Google Sites Portfolio. A Google site is a website. We will be using a Google site to share ideas and to present our apps and other work. For each app that you build you will be asked to create a web page that describes your app and gives visitors links to download and run your app. For non-programming lessons you will be asked to answer questions about a reading or to share your reflections about a contemporary issue such as "Privacy".

    By the end of this course you will be very skilled at creating and maintaining your own simple web site. Do your best to make your site attractive and informative. Your site will be one way to express yourself and "Show your stuff!"
    1. Log in to your galileoweb email: mail.galileoweb.org
    2. Click on the apps icon (the 9 little squares in the upper right hand corner). Select the Sites app.
    3. Click Create (on the left hand side).
    4. Enter the name of your site as "[Your Name]'s CSP Portfolio". e.g. Danny Tan's CSP Portfolio
    5. Select a theme for your site (optional but recommended).
    6. Under More Options, enter "computer science" for Site categories and enter "Computer Science Principles Portfolio" for Site description.
    7. Click Create (red button at the top of the page).
    8. Your Google site is now online. Clicking on the blue Share button in the upper right to edit the sharing privileges.
    9. Click on Change... and change the access to "Can view" only. Click Save.
    10. In the "Invite people" box, enter Mr. Tan's email address (tand@galileoweb.org) and click Send to share.
    11. Create the following pages (click the New page button) to be added to your navigation bar
      • Homework
      • Creative Projects
      • Reflections
      • Performance Tasks
    12. On your Home page, add whatever personal information you want to share about yourself, including a photo or image. The photo doesn't have to be a personal photo.
    13. If you would like more details about how to setup or customize your site, here's a Google site for setting up your Google site: https://sites.google.com/site/sitesetupguide/

Again, welcome to CSP! Let's have a fun and exciting year!
